cons: - Every center is different and some teams can be poorly managed - Lack of information access to clients - OTs tend to get overloaded with catch-all requests

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oakland, CA
pros: Everyone at On Lok is very dedicated to the mission and is nice to work with. Decent work life balance and pay for nonprofit sector.
cons: The organization is struggling to modernize and move into the future in many ways. Certain members of the leadership hold this back more than others. I think the organization is improving overall, i.e. in terms of building better systems internally, but it is very bureaucratic and I think many things will be slow to change.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: For the most part, I have found my time at On Lok to be a pleasant and positive one.  Most of the staff are friendly.  There is an emphasis on growth.  I also appreciate the effort to formalize and standardize many of the procedures, despite most of the long-term staff's obvious resistance.  I respect the company's mission to provide care for the elderly.
cons: There are difficult personalities in all industries.  However, it seems that many of the long-term staff are allowed to behave especially unprofessionally without any real consequences.  Many are quick to complain to upper management before truly investigating any real issues.  There is also a negative culture of refusing responsibility and placing blame on others that is allowed.  There is also an acceptance of backstabbing and gossiping that seems to be more prevalent here than anywhere else I've been.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Management are supportive and very enthusiastic.  Employees, as far as I can tell, are provided adequate resources to help them execute their tasks.  I feel very comfortable going to my direct supervisor and asking for resources and questions if needed.  Coming from previous healthcare organizations that were extremely negative and numbers-driven, I have found my experience at On Lok to be refreshing, so far.  I feel that my input is valued and that any criticism I might receive is presented professionally and in a constructive manner.  So far, I have found my coworkers and colleagues to be pleasant people.  The benefits are the best and most comprehensive I have had so far in health care career (there is even an option for discounted pet insurance!)
cons: Many of the employees who have been with the organization for a long time have little to no morale-they are extremely resistant to change and have been quite verbal about their longing for the "Old On Lok."  Many of the newer and younger employees might experience some resistance and passive-aggressive behavior from them.

job_title: Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: At its core, On Lok has an amazing mission. The immediate individuals that are a part of a senior's care team really try to take the time to get to know the senior and do their best at providing the highest standard of services possible, often going above and beyond.
cons:
The leadership team, on the other hand, is dysfunctional. It seems like they can't stand each other, and the team is fraught with corporate politics the unfortunately trickle down to the employees. Communication and transparency at the organization are non-existent. Priorities often change, and they are usually reactionary. Departments normally have projects or initiatives that are contradictory to each other,  thereby leading to confusion and mixed messaging. Brand footprint is lackluster in the broader community, and what little awareness there is about On Lok is often incorrect, and typically lukewarm to negative.

In general, the "lackeys" care about serving the seniors. but it's challenging in a dysfunctional work environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great direct services to the seniors.  You definitely can make a difference in other's life.  They treated the clients with respect and dignity.  Great services and great model.
cons: No career prospect.  Poor compensation.  They only cared to recruit new employees but did not bother to keep the existing one.  Compensation for new employees is competitive but existing employees are only able to get 2% to 3% annual adjustment, provided your performance is satisfactory.  Don't miss the chance to bargain for a better term when you first start.

job_title: Social Worker in San Jose, CA
pros: Great mission, the staff is passionate, and the team atmosphere is collaborative. I thoroughly enjoyed working here and would recommend On Lok to anyone who is passionate about improving quality of life for seniors.
cons: Office politics were tiring and often times distracting. However, I believe the intentions were good.

job_title: Administrative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Senior leadership cares, has regular town halls and is diverse.  Each location is a family.  People care for seniors and each other. Work life balance.  My manager is great.
cons: Growing pains as some want it to be the same as it was 20 years ago and have a hard time with the new better way of doing things; everyone means well so if you keep a positive attitude it works out.

review_title: A tough industry. An even tougher environment to work in.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
A great health care service product for the elderly.
The service provided is so important to an often overlooked demographic.
Honest, hardworking operational staff that really care about their work in helping low-income, chronically-ill seniors stay at home and healthy.
cons:
Increasing staff turnover.
Infrequent salary increases, barely on par with cost-of-living.
Rules are for all staff, except Senior Management.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Seeing how great the elderly were cared for.
cons:
No diversity 
Once I was hired it seemed as if my position was "new", my training was very disorganized and I was often told to read the guidelines for about 1 week straight...waste of time. The pay is not the best, don't even think of getting medical insurance if you have a family. I was paying $375 a pay check for mediocre health insurance (wasn't kaiser or blue shield, if I choose kaiser they would have taken out $600 a paycheck) I wasted no time and left.

review_title: Good intentions, good people, good cause. Nothing new in 20 years, though.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Your job is safe and work/life balance is simple.
cons: The organization and leadership is stuck chasing its tail. Nothing new, no opportunity, poor communication. It's sad because the root founders would have wanted more growth. However, it moves on like the little engine that could. Leadership needs a shake up.

job_title: Learning and Development Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great community with a fantastic overall mission.  Has a small company vibe, even though it is a medium sized company.
cons: Some jobs do not pay competitive wages, especially if you live in San Francisco proper.    Availability for promotion seems limited.

job_title: Purchasing Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The amazing work done for the elderly, combined with working at the source of information for PACE programs and working with people who are dedicated to this work is the trifecta.
cons: It's not really a downside, just a caveat: growth happens. Be prepared. It is never dull here, there is always something new happening.
